Award.AwardTitle: Bijel Processing for the Synthesis of Co-continuous Electrochemical Composites with Tunable Microstructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Composite materials with co-continuous arrangement of their constituent phases are highly valuable for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Particularly in batteries, the need to simultaneously maximize the storage capacity and power delivery of the system requires the electrodes to be made of electrochemically active composites with co-continuous morphology that is tunable at length scales relevant to their electrochemical function (nano- to tens of micrometers). To this end, the proposed program will seek to develop a new platform for the synthesis of bulk electrochemical composites with tunable co-continuous microstructure using a soft matter templating technique recently developed in the Principal Investigator?s laboratory. The approach will be based on the self-assembly of solid-stabilized emulsions that inherently have a tunable co-continuous microstructure, and subsequent chemical transformations of their different phases. The required processing conditions to convert these co-continuous soft materials into electrochemically functional composites will be systematically investigated, and the fundamental roles of the physicochemical and processing parameters in controlling their morphology and electrochemical performance will be addressed.

If successful, the proposed program will institute a new approach to the design of composite electrodes that meet the design criteria for efficient storage and rapid delivery of electrochemical energy, made possible by their unique microstructure. Because the synthesis protocol is based on self-assembly in multi-phase mixtures, it allows such materials to be readily prepared in macroscopic dimensions with co-continuous morphology that is tunable at the microscopic level. Understanding the fundamental parameters that govern the processing of these soft material templates into co-continuous composites can also have a strong impact in a diverse array of other applications including catalysis, tissue engineering, separations, and fundamental studies of transport through porous media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bicontinuous interfacially jammed emulsion gels (bijels) are a new class of soft materials that were discovered in 2007.  These materials enjoy an intriguing internal microstructure comprised of two independently continuous, interpenetrating arrangement of tubular fluid domains with tunable characteristic size, and a layer of microparticles between them. This unique morphology makes bijels a promising class of materials for template-based synthesis of co-continuous composites with applications ranging from advanced energy materials to tissue human health.  The NSF-funded program resulted in two important outcomes for the use of bijels in these applications. 

 

Intellectual Merit: First, our group developed the necessary processing techniques to transform bijels into electrochemically active composite materials with the underlying morphology of their parent bijel (see image 1, which shows a model of the synthesized composites with co-continuous arrangement of three phases: an electron-conductor shown in gray, an electrolytically active phase shown in blue, and electrolyte passages shown as voids).  The unique microstructural tunability afforded by bijels and our processing techniques enabled tuning of the energy and power densities of the resultant composite, as demonstrated with chemistry relevant to electrodes in nickel-metal hydride batteries.  Comparison to existing technologies and published reports with the same chemistry showed that our bijel-derived materials not only offer tuning of the energy and power densities of the electrode over a wide range, but also outperform materials found in the literature with similar chemistry (see image 2, which compares the power and energy density of our electrodes to values reported previously in the literature).

 

Second, using advanced microstructural characterization equipment and algorithms of computational geometry written in our laboratory, we showed how the unique morphology of bijels provides optimum, unrestricted transport paths within a bijel-derived material, which is the primary reason for the superior performance of our composites in the context of battery electrodes (see image 3, which shows how the transport junctions, shown as yellow dots, are much more uniformly distributed in space throughout a bijel-derived porous material, compared to a commonly used emulsion-based material with random pore morphology).

 

Broader Impacts: The unique morphological characteristics of bijel-derived materials characterized, and the processing techniques developed in this award are relevant to a diverse host of applications with societal impacts ranging from energy materials to electrolysis, catalysis, tissue engineering, and cell delivery. The benefits of bijel-derived scaffolds in the context of human health, particularly cell delivery and implant coatings, is currently being investigated in our laboratory. Further, the award program resulted in instructional modules implemented in a summer outreach program that aims to instill an interest in science and engineering in populations traditionally underrepresented in these disciplines. During the award duration, fifteen high school students participated in the outreach program, and unanimously reported in their questionnaires that participation in the program significantly increased their interest in a career in the STEM fields.

Modified by: Ali Mohraz

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Bicontinuous interfacially jammed emulsion gels (bijels) are a new class of soft materials that were discovered in 2007. These materials enjoy an intriguing internal microstructure comprised of two independently continuous, interpenetrating arrangement of tubular fluid domains with tunable characteristic size, and a layer of microparticles between them. This unique morphology makes bijels a promising class of materials for template-based synthesis of co-continuous composites with applications ranging from advanced energy materials to tissue human health. The NSF-funded program resulted in two important outcomes for the use of bijels in these applications. Intellectual Merit: First, our group developed the necessary processing techniques to transform bijels into electrochemically active composite materials with the underlying morphology of their parent bijel (see image 1, which shows a model of the synthesized composites with co-continuous arrangement of three phases: an electron-conductor shown in gray, an electrolytically active phase shown in blue, and electrolyte passages shown as voids). The unique microstructural tunability afforded by bijels and our processing techniques enabled tuning of the energy and power densities of the resultant composite, as demonstrated with chemistry relevant to electrodes in nickel-metal hydride batteries. Comparison to existing technologies and published reports with the same chemistry showed that our bijel-derived materials not only offer tuning of the energy and power densities of the electrode over a wide range, but also outperform materials found in the literature with similar chemistry (see image 2, which compares the power and energy density of our electrodes to values reported previously in the literature). Second, using advanced microstructural characterization equipment and algorithms of computational geometry written in our laboratory, we showed how the unique morphology of bijels provides optimum, unrestricted transport paths within a bijel-derived material, which is the primary reason for the superior performance of our composites in the context of battery electrodes (see image 3, which shows how the transport junctions, shown as yellow dots, are much more uniformly distributed in space throughout a bijel-derived porous material, compared to a commonly used emulsion-based material with random pore morphology). Broader Impacts: The unique morphological characteristics of bijel-derived materials characterized, and the processing techniques developed in this award are relevant to a diverse host of applications with societal impacts ranging from energy materials to electrolysis, catalysis, tissue engineering, and cell delivery. The benefits of bijel-derived scaffolds in the context of human health, particularly cell delivery and implant coatings, is currently being investigated in our laboratory. Further, the award program resulted in instructional modules implemented in a summer outreach program that aims to instill an interest in science and engineering in populations traditionally underrepresented in these disciplines. During the award duration, fifteen high school students participated in the outreach program, and unanimously reported in their questionnaires that participation in the program significantly increased their interest in a career in the STEM fields.
